an4.185:1.1: Once the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
an4.185:1.2: Now at that time several very well-known wanderers were residing in the monastery of the wanderers on the bank of the Sappinī river. They included Annabhāra, Varadhara, Sakuludāyī, and other very well-known wanderers.
an4.185:1.3: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to the wanderer’s monastery on the bank of the Sappinī river.
an4.185:2.1: Now at that time this discussion came up while those wanderers of other religions were sitting together,
an4.185:2.2: “The truths of the brahmins are like this; the truths of the brahmins are like that.”
an4.185:2.3: Then the Buddha went up to those wanderers, sat down on the seat spread out, and said to them,
an4.185:3.1: “Wanderers, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was left unfinished?”
an4.185:3.2: “Well, Master Gotama, this discussion came up among us while we were sitting together:
an4.185:3.3: ‘The truths of the brahmins are like this; the truths of the brahmins are like that.’”
an4.185:4.1: “Wanderers, I declare these four truths of the brahmins, having realized them with my own insight.
an4.185:4.5: Saying this, a brahmin speaks the truth, not lies.
an4.185:4.6: But they don’t think of themselves as an ‘ascetic’ or ‘brahmin’ because of that. Nor do they think ‘I’m better’ or ‘I’m equal’ or ‘I’m worse’.
an4.185:4.7: Rather, they simply practice out of kindness and compassion for living creatures, having had insight into the truth of that.
an4.185:5.2: ‘All sensual pleasures are impermanent, suffering, and perishable.’
an4.185:5.3: Saying this, a brahmin speaks the truth, not lies.
an4.185:5.4: But they don’t think of themselves as an ‘ascetic’ or ‘brahmin’ because of that. Nor do they think ‘I’m better’ or ‘I’m equal’ or ‘I’m worse’.
an4.185:5.5: Rather, they simply practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding sensual pleasures, having had insight into the truth of that.
an4.185:6.2: ‘All states of existence are impermanent, suffering, and perishable.’ … They simply practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding future lives, having had insight into the truth of that.
an4.185:7.2: ‘I don’t belong to anyone anywhere. And nothing belongs to me anywhere.’
an4.185:7.3: Saying this, a brahmin speaks the truth, not lies.
an4.185:7.4: But they don’t think of themselves as an ‘ascetic’ or ‘brahmin’ because of that. Nor do they think ‘I’m better’ or ‘I’m equal’ or ‘I’m worse’.
an4.185:7.5: Rather, they simply practice the path of nothingness, having had insight into the truth of that.
an4.185:7.6: These are the four truths of the brahmins that I declare, having realized them with my own insight.”
